greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle T(n,k) = Sum_{j=0..k/2} binomial(n-j-1,k-2*j), read by rows.
link: G. C. Greubel, Rows n = 1..100 of triangle, flattened
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Steenrod Algebra
example: The triangle starts in row n=1 with columns 0 <= k < 2*n:
maple: seq(seq(sum(binomial(n-j-1, k-2*j), j=0..floor(k/2)), k=0..2*n-1), n=1..10); # _G. C. Greubel_, Sep 05 2019
mathematica: Table[Sum[Binomial[n-j-1, k-2*j], {j,0,Floor[k/2]}], {n, 10}, {k, 0, 2*n-1}]//Flatten (* modified by _G. C. Greubel_, Sep 05 2019 *)
program: for(n=1,10, for(k=0,2*n-1, print1(T(n,k), ", "))) \\ _G. C. Greubel_, Sep 05 2019
(MAGMA) [&+[Binomial(n-j-1, k-2*j): j in [0..Floor(k/2)]]: k in [0..2*n-1], n in [1..10]]; // _G. C. Greubel_, Sep 05 2019
(Sage) [[sum(binomial(n-j-1, k-2*j) for j in (0..floor(k/2))) for k in (0..2*n-1)] for n in (1..10)] # _G. C. Greubel_, Sep 05 2019
(GAP) Flat(List([1..10], n-> List([0..2*n-1], k-> Sum([0..Int(k/2)], j-> Binomial(n-j-1, k-2*j) )))); # _G. C. Greubel_, Sep 05 2019
results.author: _Roger L. Bagula_, Nov 14 2006
